Title: Slim, silent, low-heat, great battery & portability
ReviewText: My priorities in searching for a laptop were as follows: good brand, low emission (meaning low heat and low noise), MATTE display (because the common glossy displays reflect way too much light), HD monitor, >8GB RAM and a Solid State Drive. I spent a lot of time reviewing newegg, bestbuy and amazon for top sellers, along with pcreviews and notebookcheck dot net (which does incredible detailed reviews showing how much heat and noise a laptop generates). I settled on this notebook and am very happy with what I got. The 2018 version is definitely worth the extra $50 over the 2017 version because the bezel (plastic border around the screen) is much smaller resulting in a laptop that is 10% smaller than the 2017 version while maintaining a 13" screen! The faint high pitched noise put out by the motherboard is only detectable in a silent room when you place your head within 12" of the keyboard. The battery life is stellar. Under load, the system hardly generates any heat and under light use (browsing/Word), I never hear the fan kick in. This 8th generation i5 is much more powerful than older i7 CPU's. It's incredibly thin. I was worried about the laptop looking 'gold' but it doesn't - it looks very silver with a faint hue. Very fast start-ups - I press the power button from hibernation and by the time I moved my finger to the fingerprint, I'm up and running within 2 seconds. Fully recommend.

Title: Great Hardware.  Windows 10....meh
ReviewText: Out of the box the X1 Carbon is an impressive machine. Very light weight and aesthetically pleasing. The keyboard is a pleasure to use and the touchpad is much better than other PCs I've recently used. The model I have has the standard 1920 x 1080 display which is fine for an ultraportable. Should you desire something comparable to a Mac Retina display, I recommend upgrading to the Lenovo hi-res HDR display. For typical business use - email, MS Office, web browsing, video conferencing, etc., the Intel 8th Gen i5 processor, 256GB SSD and 8GB RAM configuration is fine. The X1 also has a good array of ports including USB A-type, USB-C/Thunderbolt, and HDMI. After a few days of use, battery life is impressive -- probably 10 hours with web browsing, Office, and email usage. The only knock I'd give it in terms of hardware is the lid has a lot of flex to it, but I suppose this is to be expected since it's not aluminum. The other negative is not the fault of the hardware, but rather Windows 10. Setup was tedious. After going through multiple rounds of updates taking a couple of hours, I had to do a full reset and start over because the Start Menu would not save any changes. I would delete the Windows Games and other bloatware I don't need only to have it reappear. I am not set up on a domain where a Group Policy is doing this, so I decided to reset and that solved the problem. I also had to do a BIOS update and some Lenovo-dictated driver updates. After three days of use, all has been good. Within this price range, I have recently used a Microsoft Surface Laptop and a new Dell XPS 13 and prefer this Lenovo to either of those.

Title: Think twice if you plan to use with docking station
ReviewText: Laptop performance itself seems to be fine. A little heavy for frequent travelers. Trackpad is the best I've used on a laptop. The i7-6700HQ does not, and thus, I experienced a lot of crashes in higher-end titles, most likely from that processor. Considering it was from Dell and not an overpriced behemoth from their Alienware lineup, my old Inspiron was good, but my MSI is downright outstanding. Title: It's a hot unstable mess
ReviewText: The laptop looks great, but I don't have anything else good to say about it. It is thermal throttling 100% of the time, as much as 30%. I can't even browse the internet and enjoy a stable system. Fans will randomly turn into jet engines when doing nothing to tax the CPU or GPU. Title: This computer is hands down the best laptop I've ever used
ReviewText: This computer is hands down the best laptop I've ever used. The display is very color accurate and pretty, but it's mind-blowing fast. It does run warm whenever under a lot of load (75 C), but I'm yet to see it throttle. When it does get warm though the fans go into overboost and cool it back down quickly. They are audible very slightly in balanced mode, a bit noisy in overboost, but extremely quiet in silent. The computer runs fast, quiet, and very smooth. The only upgrade I see myself purchasing is an extra 16 gb stick of ram to supplement the current one. I have only one "complaint" with this whole computer. I knew this going into it, but any PC with components like these and a display with G-Sync battery life is gonna be bad, but be ready to keep the charger nearby. I get close to 3 hours with the brightness at 50% and no audio. That's just being on the web and streaming netflix through a wireless headset. Gaming is closer to the 2 hour mark. Aside from this though, I don't believe there's a better gaming laptop out there under $2,000 dollars.

Title: Has its flaws but with a little work is great!
ReviewText: Overall, the laptop is great. I ordered the one with the smaller hard drive as I already had plans on swapping existing SSD's into the unit that were larger and performed better. I was surprised to see a Samsung M.2 NVMe SSD in the unit that was a decent performer which I considered a bonus as I was expecting one of lesser quality. The laptop is gorgeous. The screen is beautiful and the blacks are amazing. Physically, this thing is great but slightly flimsy which was done to cut down on weight, so "I get it". On the lesser side of things, the drive partitioning was weird. I had a 256GB drive that had two separate partitions, a 133GB partition for C: (Windows OS) and an 88GB for D: (Data?). Odd to say the least. Also, when I booted into a live linux USB and fired up gparted to fix this, I noticed that there was a partition in between the two making it a little more challenging than simply deleting a partition and expanding the other. Now, I had to delete the "data" partition, move the offending "in-betweener" partition and then expand the Windows OS partition. Next was removing as much bloatware as possible. Windows 10 bloatware, MSI bloatware, you name it, it's on there. So essentially, it took the better part of a day to get the laptop "where I wanted it" which in my opinion is a little much. The BIOS. There are no options for memory speed settings or XMPP profiles. There are no temperature monitoring settings. Spartan to say the least. The laptop is advertised as supporting memory up to 2666mhz, yet when I installed 3200mhz ram, it did not "auto-detect" the new ram speed or 2666mhz, nor were there any settings in the bios to adjust the timings or speed. This must be addressed by MSI. There are two slots for m.2 SSD drives but the motherboard is flipped upside-down so one must remove the motherboard from the laptop in order to install/change the ram or the hard drive. The "Killer" wifi was horrible. I changed it out with an Intel 9260 and am much happier.

Title: Much better than I could imagine.
ReviewText: This is what we could name as a perfect product to produce and edit videos, working as a pro paying much, much less than an equivalent Apple. It does support dual Wi-Fi frequencies, using at high-speed all the potential of the Fiber channel service that I have at home without any cable. Be prepared to purchase a bigger backpack or equivalent case. I buy one here at Amazon but I feel worth to go a Best Buy or equivalent store and find a better product due time restrictions in U.S. (the one purchase here has a ocassional problem, the laptop zipper container stucks at the fabric sometimes). I have payed something like 2x more for the Wenger 17' inch backpack at BB but you could find at a good price here at Amazon (Wenger Ibex Laptop Backpack).

Title: fast machine when configured properly; 2 little peeves
ReviewText: Configured w/ i7-8550U, 32GB RAM, 512GB SSD + 1TB HD, Win10 Pro 64bit, pen and touch support. Very fast, multiple windows open simultaneously, spreadsheets are a breeze, great video. Two minor peeves: 1. NumLock key doesn't have a light to indicate it is on/off (does make a different sound for "on" vs "off", as does the CapsLock key -- but CapsLock key also has a light), 2. No dedicated right- and left-click keys under touch pad; rather -- the touchpad right-bottom-corner is your Right-click. These are minor peeves. Overall, a superb machine.

Title: Amazing machine

Title: The buttons are on the back, otherwise I love it
ReviewText: I have an older version of this monitor and wanted to add a second monitor with a stand but I wanted them to match. The outside dimensions and looks are almost identical to the old one but the buttons are on the back on this one. I originally had it on the left to replace my Samsung monitor but had to move this one to the right in order to have access to the power button. I would not be happy if I bought two of these for my stand and have to reach over or under to use any of the buttons. The picture quality is awesome though and better than my older one, so I am happy for the most part. If this will be a stand alone monitor for you I would definitely recommend it!

Title: Power button stinks!
ReviewText: Ahhh man, I think I goofed with this product. I absolutely loved this laptop for the short time that I had it. I just wish the power button wasn’t the way it was. It’s like this tiny little pointed rectangle on the side and is even hard to press sometimes. What’s worse is it broke on me! Now I can’t turn the laptop on. This happened months ago and now the laptop is just sitting there, but now after getting a new laptop I wish I could use this one sometimes. I was walking into a narrow doorway and the side of the laptop seemingly barely GRAZED the side of the wall and that was all it took for the power button to be almost completely dented inside the laptop. I’ve reached out to HP but they charge way too much for what should be a simple repair. Besides this, the laptop WAS incredible, and this is coming from someone engulfed in the Apple Eco System.

There are multiple issues not to mention freezing, not turning off, over heating and Windows defender not defending. The original issue was updates failed.

Title: This would of been a great laptop but the power button stopped working
ReviewText: This would of been a great laptop but the power button stopped working. I loved every aspect of this laptop but the second day we had it I could not get it to power on after a shutdown without a lot of effort. I had to hold down the power button multiple times for like 20 seconds and then unplug the laptop. After doing this dance a 3 - 5 times the laptop would boot. Sometimes it would boot into a black screen with a CMOS checksum error. So I open a ticket with HP and spent hours reloading win 10, patching and reloading the BIos, which did not work. So I am returning it today since I did notice someone else with the same problem on Amazon and searching the internet it seemed like this is common.

Title: Perfect Second Monitor for Working at Home
ReviewText: This monitor was so simple to hook up. It came with the necessary cables. I did have to contact my IT guy to make it a separate screen from my laptop other than a duplicate but that’s because I am not tech savvy. I watched him do it when we shared screens though and it was a simple fix.

Title: Overheating
ReviewText: I used this laptop very lightly (no more than 6 hrs/week) for about 5-6 months before I began to get a System Fan (90b) error message on startup. I worked through all the solutions suggested by HP including cleaning vents (the device was immaculate and had been exceptionally well cared for - always enclosed in a sleeve when not in use), updating the Bios, etc. I could not get a response from the seller - the device was then out of their warranty period. I continued to use it as I was out of the country, and just did as little as possible to prevent damage from overheating. Last week I spent $187 on a repair service to confirm that the device is indeed overheating (not just a bogus error message), and that the fans look fine, nothing in the vents, no dust, just that the fans don't come on so no cooling. They tested some of the other components as well - but no solution. They suspect a bad motherboard. However I've ordered new fans on the off chance 2 perfect appearing fans went bad in 5-6 months of very light use. I really loved this laptop - it worked well for me and was so light and easy to use in my travels. I did install an app to monitor the temperature and hibernate when it overheats. But since it overheats quickly and goes into hibernation as soon as I start to do much of anything, that isn't a solution. I've had to switch back to my heavy ThinkPad. Just hoping the new fans (another $$$) will solve the problem.

Title: Disappointing
ReviewText: Love this for the keyboard, lightness and flexibility. Power port went bad after 9 months and it was a nightmare to have it repaired by HP. Unit was clearly under warranty as confirmed by search but once the unit arrived at HP no communication from them for several weeks. When I finally reached them they insisted I had to upload sales receipt, etc even though their OWN database clearly showed it under warranty. Was without unit for almost 2 months for that repair. Now 5 months later power port is going bad again and getting a fan error message. Nice machine if you don't mind giving it up for constant repairs. Not worth the cost.
